name: Trinity College Dublin
visaRiskNotes: Strong institution profile typically reduces credibility concerns, but applicants still must meet financial evidence and academic progression rules.

name: University College Dublin
visaRiskNotes: Generally low risk when documentation is consistent, however applications can be scrutinised for funds, academic fit, and progression.

name: University College Cork
visaRiskNotes: Low institutional risk, but visa decisions still depend on funds, academic logic, and compliance with student permission rules.

name: University of Galway
visaRiskNotes: Low risk in general, however applicants should ensure course choice aligns with prior study and financial documents are complete.

name: Dublin City University
visaRiskNotes: Public university profile is typically favourable, but some part time routes can have visa constraints, so students should choose full time eligible programmes.

name: University of Limerick
visaRiskNotes: Visa assessment still depends on academic rationale and finances, even for strong public institutions.

name: Maynooth University
visaRiskNotes: Generally low risk, however students should document commute and accommodation plans if living outside Dublin.

name: Technological University Dublin
visaRiskNotes: Public TU profile is generally acceptable, but applicants should show strong academic progression and clear course outcomes.

name: Munster Technological University
visaRiskNotes: Typically defensible for visa if full time and properly documented, but outcomes are still assessed case by case.

name: Technological University of the Shannon
visaRiskNotes: Newer TU brand can prompt additional scrutiny on study plan quality, so documentation should be tight.

name: Atlantic Technological University
visaRiskNotes: Regional multi campus study plans should clearly specify campus and programme, because ambiguity can hurt visa credibility.

name: South East Technological University
visaRiskNotes: Regional location is not a visa negative by itself, however applicants should show realistic accommodation and cost planning.

name: Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland University of Medicine and Health Sciences
visaRiskNotes: Strongly recognised institution, but health and medicine routes typically face higher documentation expectations and higher cost evidence.

name: National College of Ireland
visaRiskNotes: Private college applicants can face higher scrutiny for academic progression and finances, so course logic and funding evidence must be consistent.

name: Dublin Business School
visaRiskNotes: Private sector institutions can face closer credibility checks, so students should avoid weak study rationales and show clear academic relevance.

name: Griffith College
visaRiskNotes: Private college route can be viable, but visa review can focus on programme quality, progression, and funds, therefore keep documentation conservative.

name: National College of Art and Design
visaRiskNotes: Portfolio based routes require strong evidence of academic fit, and unclear fit can raise questions even if the institution is public.

name: Institute of Art, Design and Technology, Dun Laoghaire
visaRiskNotes: Creative programmes can be scrutinised for study logic and portfolio strength, even when visa risk is otherwise low.

name: Mary Immaculate College
visaRiskNotes: Education and humanities pathways should clearly justify return on study and progression to avoid credibility concerns.

name: University of Galway International Summer School
visaRiskNotes: Short duration or visiting style programmes can have different permission rules, so applicants must ensure the visa category matches programme length.

name: American College Dublin
visaRiskNotes: Smaller private institutions can face higher scrutiny, so applicants should be conservative and avoid weak academic narratives or unclear funding.

name: IBAT College Dublin
visaRiskNotes: Lower visibility institutions can be scrutinised more for credibility, therefore financial evidence, attendance intent, and course relevance must be exceptionally clear.

name: University College Dublin Professional Academy
visaRiskNotes: Short professional courses may not align with standard full time student permission expectations, so applicants must ensure the correct permission route.

name: City Colleges
visaRiskNotes: Part time and short course providers often do not support standard student permission pathways, therefore avoid using as a visa anchor.

name: Irish Management Institute
visaRiskNotes: Executive and part time formats can create visa constraints, so full time eligibility should be verified for any programme used for immigration purposes.

name: UCD Michael Smurfit Graduate Business School
visaRiskNotes: Competitive business admissions require clear academics, GMAT where needed, and strong funds, otherwise refusal risk rises even with a top institution.
